It covers the following pieces of information: 
Six people were injured in an explosion at an oil storage facility at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian Province, China. The blast occurred Monday night due to an oil leak. Five of the six injured were hurt by broken glass with one sent to the hospital in critical condition. There has been no report of a toxic chemical spill by local media. The fire is currently under control and more than 600 firefighters have been dispatched. Residents living close to the plant expressed concern on Weibo, and protests have occurred in the area in recent years against the plant's production of paraxylene (PX), a carcinogenic chemical. The plant was originally slated for Xiamen, but relocation to its current remote location occurred due to pollution concerns.

The passage discusses the alarming increase in the number of children born with Foetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS). According to the World Health Organisation, at least one in 100 UK babies are born with FAS, which can cause physical, learning and behavioural problems. These include deformed limbs, cerebral palsy and sight loss. It is believed that the actual number of children affected by FAS may be much higher, as the condition is often under-diagnosed. The government advises pregnant women to avoid alcohol, but some experts believe this guidance should be strengthened to encourage complete abstinence.

Indiana's Gov. Mike Pence approved a short-term needle exchange program last month to help curb the state's largest-ever HIV outbreak. In the first weeks of the program, 5,322 clean syringes have been provided to 86 participants, and about 1,400 used syringes have been returned. However, as the number of HIV cases grows, pressure mounts on Pence to extend the program beyond April 25. Pence, who opposes needle exchanges as an anti-drug policy, has said he will decide early next week.

A new video shows a Labrador called Cooper eating his McDonald's ice cream in one bite. His owner, Katie Gallegos says Cooper always eats quickly, so she makes sure his pal Daisy, eats first. To date the video of Cooper's ice cream outing has been watched more than seven million times.

The passage highlights the high landing fees faced by those who travel via private jet; a privilege only afforded to the ultra wealthy. The piece notes that the fees can give insight into which airports are most popular for the super rich, and lists 10 airports by the high cost of their landing fees. In order they are: 
1. Haneda Airport, Tokyo 
2. Narita International Airport, Tokyo 
3. Kansai International Airport, Osaka 
4. Toronto Pearson International Airport, Toronto 
5. Darwin International Airport, Darwin 
6. Bristol Airport, Bristol 
7. Chūbu Centrair International Airport, Nagoya 
8. Dublin Airport
9. La Guardia Airport, New York 
10. Salzburg Airport, Salzburg 

The passage also notes that Tokyo's Haneda airport is by far the most expensive, charging £4,559 ($6,850) for landing privileges and serving almost 69 million passengers per year.

New research shows that the art of washing one's own car is dying out in Britain -- only 12% of men say they do it regularly, and a whopping 71% of women never wash their own cars. As reasons, survey participants cited the rise of hand car washes, the prevalence of football on television on Sundays, and the fact that many cars are too large to clean. Brits are most likely to wash their own cars during holidays, with 15 million estimated to have done so during the recent Easter break. The study was conducted by vehicle leasing firm OSV, which surveyed 1,100 adults.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting sales registers at company-operated stores across the United States and Canada. The disruption, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, prompted baristas to give away free drinks and baked goods. Many locations closed to prevent giving away free products. The company released a statement saying that they are working to resolve the outage, and that stores will remain open. This comes just one day after the company posted record quarterly earnings.

Open Garden's FireChat allows users to chat to friends without the need for the web or a mobile signal. It does this by accessing iOS 7's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF), which creates a wireless mesh network that connects phones to each other, allowing messages to be sent via Bluetooth or Wi-Fi Direct. Greenstone acts as a beacon or booster for these networks, helping to strengthen and extend them. FireChat has been downloaded more than 5 million times and Greenstone is currently under development. It is expected to reach commercial availability sometime this year.

Jack Grealish, an Irish international footballer at Aston Villa, is superstitious and refuses to cover his shins with his socks as he believes this brings him luck. He made his first Premier League start on Tuesday against QPR. He hopes to get more starts before the end of the season.

Tim Sherwood, Aston Villa manager, has told Jack Grealish to focus on becoming a first team regular at Villa Park and not be concerned with his international future, as the 19-year-old is wanted by England and the Republic of Ireland. Grealish, who recently signed a new contract at Villa, made his first team debut in March 2015, and has made 22 appearances to date. Sherwood says he told Nabil Bentaleb, now at Tottenham, to go with his heart when he was deciding whether to play for Algeria or France, and that's what he's telling Grealish to do as well.

Sarah Wilson, journalist and author, opens up about her battle with mental illness, specifically anxiety. She explains that her anxiety and depression led her to contemplate taking her own life. She describes the point as being one where she could not see a way out and referred to it as an "existential crisis". She believes that her anxiety and depression are intrinsically linked and that this is a common phenomenon.

Laura Scurr was obsessed with having a perfect figure and blended mashed potato into her meals to hide the fact she wasn't eating.
The 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, whose heart rate had slowed after just a week of eating virtually nothing, collapsed and was rushed to hospital.
She spent a week on a heart monitor at North Tyneside General Hospital before she was offered support by eating disorder organisations and began her recovery.

The core pieces of information are as follows:
- A suicide bomber in Afghanistan killed 17 people and wounded 64 others.
- The bomber attacked a group of protesters, including Afghan lawmaker Faizullah Ghairat.
- The protesters were headed to a larger rally to protest the provincial governor. 
- The Taliban has denied responsibility for the attack. No other organization has claimed responsibility.

Gary Locke has signed a deal to become Kilmarnock manager on a permanent basis after an interim spell following the departure of Allan Johnston. Johnston, Locke's former team mate at Tynecastle, left Rugby Park at the start of February with the club struggling near the foot of the Scottish Premiership table. Kilmarnock have lost just once in seven games since 41-year-old Locke's arrival and he has now signed a three-year deal.

Four Liverpool players were surprised when they met YouTube star and free-kick specialist Bas van Velzen at their training ground.
Van Velzen, who has become a sensation by uploading free-kick videos to YouTube, met Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert and Lazar Markovic after winning a competition.

Every day, Lu Xin Cai takes his Alzheimer's suffering 84-year-old mother on the back of his motorbike to work. He ties a sash around both their waists for safety. When he was younger, his mother would often go up to the mountains to collect firewood and a few times, she got lost. After his father passed away, Xin Cai is the only one who can look after her as his wife works in a different city and his son is still in school. Even when at work, he checks up on his mother as his employers, a bank, gave her her own room.

Manchester United have made an official approach for PSV Eindhoven's Memphis Depay, with the club's technical director confirming their interest.
United manager Louis van Gaal is familiar with the player, having selected him for Holland's 2014 World Cup squad.
The versatile Depay can play on the left or right wing and his impressive dribbling skills see him complete the most dribbles in the entire Eredivise.
The 21-year-old has scored 20 goals in 26 league games for PSV this season and was the Dutch league's top scorer this year.
He has already made over 100 appearances for the Dutch giants and is under contract until 2018.

Manchester United have made an official approach for PSV Eindhoven's Memphis Depay, with the club's technical director confirming their interest.
United manager Louis van Gaal is familiar with the player, having selected him for Holland's 2014 World Cup squad.
The versatile Depay can play on the left or right wing and his impressive dribbling skills see him complete the most dribbles in the entire Eredivise.
The 21-year-old has scored 20 goals in 26 league games for PSV this season and was the Dutch league's top scorer this year.
He scored in PSV's 4-1 win over Heerenveen which sealed the Dutch title.
Depay, who was born in 1994, started out at VV Moordrecht before joining Sparta Rotterdam aged nine and then moving to PSV aged 12.
He signed his first professional contract in June 2012 and has made over 100 appearances for the Dutch giants.

Robin van Persie will not feature in the Manchester Derby on Sunday due to a persistent ankle injury as announced by Manchester United manager Louis Van Gaal on Friday. Despite Van Persie's earlier comments that he was fit to play, Van Gaal does not believe the player is match fit. Luke Shaw is also out of the game due to lack of match fitness, however, Van Gaal said he cannot yet rule out either player's return as he believes in making his own decisions on when players are ready. The Dutch manager is looking forward to the game, saying "I dream of it. Every player should dream of the victory". Van Gaal goes into the game hoping to finish in the top three of the Premier League and avoid a Champions League play-off.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has admitted that he is disappointed in the performances of Yaya Toure this season but says that the midfielder will have his support until the end of the season.
Sportsmail revealed that City will listen to offers for Toure in the summer as they look to overhaul an ageing squad. Toure, who has two years left on his £220,000-a-week deal, has come under criticism amid the collapse of City's Premier League defence. Pellegrini said, "I don't think he's happy with his performance this year -- and nor am I," the Chilean said. "He doesn't need a break.

Martin Skrtel believes that Steven Gerrard, who is set to leave Liverpool at the end of the season, is one of the best players in the world and will be sorely missed, but that the team has the personnel to fill the void. Skrtel said that Gerrard had helped him immensely since he joined the club and that he was grateful for that. Liverpool face Aston Villa in the FA Cup semi-final on Sunday, with the winner set to face either Arsenal or Reading in the final.

Michael Shemansky is on the run after it is believed he murdered his mother. Shemansky failed to appear for a visit with his son on the same day as his mother's death. He has a history of bipolar disorder and was committed to a psychiatric ward for an attempted suicide in the past. His mother was helping him through divorce proceedings. It is believed the stress caused by the divorce caused him to murder his mother. He is on parole for battery of a law enforcement officer.

Mike Brown is being cautious over a recent concussion and refuses to put a time scale on his return for Harlequins. Brown recently pulled out of the England-Ireland game feeling the after-effects of a headache. This is in response to increased awareness of the symptoms of concussion that players undergo as part of their world rugby online modules.

Mike Brown is being cautious over a recent concussion and refuses to put a time scale on his return for Harlequins. Brown recently pulled out of the England-Ireland game feeling the after-effects of a headache. This is in response to increased awareness of the symptoms of concussion that players undergo as part of their world rugby online modules.

Mr Mole is 7-2 co-favourite for the Grade One Celebration Chase which AP McCoy will ride on his last day as a professional jockey. The Paul Nicholls-trained horse will be one of seven running in the race at Sandown on Saturday, with Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's Sacre the other co-favourites. It was after riding Mr Mole to victory at Newbury in February that McCoy revealed his decision to retire.

The New York City police hope that the public can help identify a woman found dead last month in Brooklyn so they can notify her family. The NYPD released images of a distinctive tattoo on her right leg to help with identification. Anyone with information is asked to contact the NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

Eden Hazard and young Nathan Ake took part in Audi's football challenge, paired up against Loic Remy and Willian in a series of football-related games for the car manufacturers. The first challenge was to fire balls into the boot of a car from close range, which was won by Hazard and Ake, who won 5-3. The second challenge was to sink balls into convertible Audis from long range, which was again won by Hazard and Ake, winning the decider to take a 6-0 lead after the first two rounds. In the final challenge, which earned the most points, the players had to shoot from long range aiming to sink their footballs through the roof of a convertible Audi. Remy and Willian won this, but in the process, Willian smashed the wing mirror off one of the Audis with a long-range effort, prompting a comical reaction from Loic Remy.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde left London over a year ago with no plans, no agenda and no cause to fight for. Rather, the Spanish and Latvian cyclists simply had a dream to see more of the planet. In the 356 days since then, they've covered 7,000 miles on bikes, spending less than three euros per day between them. Their budget keeps down costs by relying on free accommodation and no transport costs, and they pitch a tent or camp most nights. This leaves food as their main expense, with the pair eating pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, seasonal fruits and vegetables, and occasionally picking up wild fruits.

In the 356 days since then, they've covered 7,000 miles on bikes, spending less than three euros per day between them. Their budget keeps down costs by relying on free accommodation and no transport costs, and they pitch a tent or camp most nights. This leaves food as their main expense, with the pair eating pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, seasonal fruits and vegetables, and occasionally picking up wild fruits.

Pablo Osvaldo wants Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at Argentine club Boca Juniors. Osvaldo feels they would be well received by the fans and that their South American style would suit the club. Pirlo is a world class midfielder whilst Totti has starred for Roma.

Police dropped investigation into the assault of Mike Lane 3 months after it took place. Victim condemned the decision as pathetic. Attackers not likely to be found unless further evidence comes forward. Victim feels let down and thinks police could've done more. Police have failed to identify, charge or prosecute anyone involved.

Liverpool paraded their new home kit for next season at Anfield on Friday, with stars including Raheem Sterling and Daniel Sturridge present.
Sterling was the subject of supporter chants telling him to "hold nothing back", in response to his comments last week that he had rejected a £100,000-a-week contract and been flattered by an approach from Arsenal.
The new kit, designed by sponsors New Balance, features white branding and an all-new collar style. New Balance struck a £300m four-year deal to replace Warrior as Liverpool's suppliers.

The rail companies are to be condemned for their planned fare hikes; some fares are set to increase by as much as 87%. The Prime Minister, David Cameron, has requested that the First Great Western rail company review its decision due to the planned changes affecting his Witney constituency. Research by trainsplit.com discovered that hundreds of 'anytime' and 'off-peak' returns rose by 40% in January. However, Virgin Trains argue that their increases only affect 'Virgin Trains-only fares', and that these tickets are 20% cheaper than competitor tickets.

The passage discusses the damage caused by severe weather in New South Wales, Australia last week with heavy rain and floods. It also warns residents that another storm is predicted to hit the state later this week, with the potential for heavy rain from Thursday through to Saturday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that more storms will hamper clean-up efforts, with 4,409 of the 24,196 jobs still needing to be completed. The SES is particularly worried about the effect more wild weather will have on the hard-hit Hunter Region. The Bureau of Meteorology has advised residents to prepare their homes and families ahead of time.

Rory McIlroy hopes to complete the career grand slam by winning the Masters at Augusta National. The world number one wants to join Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus and Tiger Woods as the only players to have won all four major titles. McIlroy was embarrassed by being outscored by his marker during the third round of the Masters last year, but he sees the event as a potential sanctuary where he can escape from outside pressures.

Russia are on the verge of making the Fed Cup final after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point in defeating Sabine Lisicki and thereby giving Russia a 2-0 lead over Germany. Russia need just one win from Sunday's three matches to reach the final.

The queen rides her fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, without a helmet, as she has done all her life. In 2019, in an interview, her racing trainer, Ian Balding, recalled the moment he asked the queen why she never wore a riding hat. Supposedly, the queen replied, "I never have and you don't have to have your hair done like I do." Fell ponies, the breed of the queen's mount, are one of the oldest equine breeds, dating back to the neolithic period in Cumbria. They were used by the carvetii, the iron age tribe who occupied the region, and later by the romans as trade goods. The romans helped develop the breed to be a relatively large animal. Originally thought to have stood at around 12hh, by the end of the roman period, the average fell was more than a hand higher. The usefulness of the fell pony as a pack animal was well-established by the 13th century and the animals played an important role in British trade until the end of the 18th century. Today, the fell pony remains a popular choice for riders of all ages and the queen breeds them at her Hampton Court stud.

Terrorists are being trained in rural areas of West Wales, it was disclosed today.
Locations in Ceredigion, Powys and Pembrokeshire are also being used to radicalise Muslims, according to an officer at the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit.
The news came as it was revealed that one of the killers of soldier Lee Rigby had studied Arabic in Wales.
Michael Adebowale, who was convicted of murdering Drummer Rigby in May 2013, is understood to have studied the language at the former European Institute of Human Sciences at Highmead, near Llanybydder.

Lacey Spears was sentenced to 20 years to life for the murder by poisoning of her son Garnett, 5, at a New York area hospital in January.
Her ex-husband and the boy's father, Chris Hill, posted on Facebook this week: 'Please put her in general population! Thats all im asking for! Because she wont make it!'
He also wrote: 'Crazy a** woman needs to be beat to death in prison... she has no emotion what so ever... WTH!'
Spears showed no emotion when sentenced. The judge said the 31-year-old from Kentucky suffers from mental illness.

Carwyn Scott-Howell, 7, separated from his mother while skiing and entered woodland, where he fell over a 164ft drop, investigators have revealed.
His family paid tribute to the 'adorable, caring' boy, saying he 'made life full of laughter with never a dull moment'.
The family, from Talybont-on-Usk in Wales, were on holiday in the resort of Flaine.
Police were led to the boy's body by footprints in the snow, which were broken up by 'sliding marks' for the sharper inclines.

A new map shows how the distribution of dark matter corresponds to the rate of galaxy formation. The map was created by the Dark Energy Survey (DES), which is led by the US Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory and involves more than 300 scientists from 10 countries. It is the largest single map of dark matter ever produced and was compiled using data gathered by the 570-megapixel Dark Energy Camera. To create the map, the researchers analysed 130 million telescope images of galaxies. At present, the map covers 0.4% of the sky but the scientists plan to increase this to 12.5% over the next five years. Studying the map should reveal more about the nature of dark matter and dark energy.

Celebrations for Andy Murray’s 500th win and Serena Williams’ 700th career victory dominated the headlines at the Miami Open.
Williams beat Germany’s Sabine Lisicki 7-6 , 1-6 , 6-3 to reach the semi-finals, where she will face Romania’s Simona Halep, who beat Sloane Stephens 6-1 , 7-5.
The American’s hopes of a reunion with sister Venus were ended by Spain’s Carla Suarez Navarro.

The US regulator, ICANN, is querying a Canadian company's domain name registry relating to the new 'dot sucks' domain, querying whether the actions of Vox Populi Registry Ltd are illegal. Many celebrities and major companies have had to pay sums of around $2,499 to have their names removed from the 'sucks' domains. These include; Kevin Spacey, Visa, Yahoo, Bank of America and Bing. ICANN approved the top-level domain name, however, it is now backtracking due to complaints from industry groups and companies such as Microsoft, Verizon and Ebay. Vox Populi began accepting registrations for the domain on the 30th of March.

Theo Walcott has become accustomed to bench duty this season, having been named as a substitute in 17 of Arsenal's 33 Premier League games this season -- but the winger will hope for a recall when the Gunners face Hull on Monday.

Walcott and his team-mates were pictured on a different kind of bench for a photoshoot for Paris' oldest fashion house Lanvin.

The passage describes an event where the pool at the icebergs club in Bondi was drained and used as a catwalk for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The pool was used as an unusual location for a fashion show, and the event was attended by guests who were treated to nibbles and drinks while they watched the show. The collection was a monochrome unisex line of clothing designed to be worn in 20 different ways.

Teenager Lewis Ferguson was flung from his horse during a race at Wincanton and took a spectacular fall. The 18-year-old, who has emerged unscathed, has since joked he may have a career in gymnastics after finishing racing.

A baby hippo became the unwitting victim of a fight between two adult hippos in South Africa.
The five-day-old calf was thrown into the air after being caught between the jaws of one of the adults, with its mother looking on helplessly. The baby hippo died of its injuries hours later.
Gemma the pit bull lives in California with her human family and spits out broccoli when offered to her.

Photographer Atif Saeed went 10 feet from a lion in a Pakistani safari park to take its picture. Saeed, who was not hunting, took a few pictures before the lion heard the shutter and charged. He said afterwards he would not do it again as it was too close an encounter.

The video shows a light general aviation aircraft approaching a residential airpark and touching down without its landing gear. The plane's propellers can be heard ricocheting off the ground as the wings bounce up and down from the impact. The pilot re-engages the engines and takes off back into the air. The most common cause of a gear-up landing is human error, and the FAA is said to be investigating the incident.

Heartwarming and tricky, the two-legged piglet is the newest internet sensation. Born without back legs, the piglet forages for food on its two front trotters, unsteadily but with remarkable balance. Many have flocked to see the curious animal, including those in China's guangxi province who went to see a similar celebrity, a rabbit at liuzhou zoo that learned to walk on its front paws.

The discovery of a drone carrying radioactive material on the roof of Japanese Prime Minister's residence is causing alarm over what appears to be a drone-based terrorism attempt. Japanese law currently restricts drone flights around airports to prevent problems with aircraft, but there is no such restriction in place for the Prime Minister's residence. The amount of radioactive material discovered on the drone was not immediately harmful to humans, according to officials.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott has come under fire for skolling a beer at a university function, with anti-drinking campaigners saying he was glorifying binge drinking. On Saturday night, Mr Abbott was asked to have a drink by University of Technology Sydney Bats coach Simon Carradous, and it took the Prime Minister about six seconds to down the schooner. Cultural studies professor Julie Robert warned that it sent a message that "drinking wasn't about socialising with friends, it was about how quickly and how much you can drink". However, Health Minister Sussan Ley jumped to Mr Abbott's defence, saying there was "nothing wrong" with his antics. "If more people got up at 4.30am and went running and cycling and worked as hard as our prime minister to keep fit and demonstrate that there are many ways that you can do this, I think we'd have a healthier country as a result," she said.

Actor Robert Hardy, known for playing Winston Churchill and for the BBC series 'All Creatures Great and Small', is selling his vast antique collection at auction, having decided to downsize.
The collection, which includes paintings, furniture, swords and rifles, reflects Hardy's interests in medieval history and classic literature.
The sale includes a diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, which was commissioned by Hardy himself from artist LM Rendall in the 1960s, and a longbow made from yew with a mother-of-pearl handle.
Hardy, 89, studied English with JRR Tolkien and is now a military historian.

West Ham have invited and been impressed by Deshane Beckford who is a 17 year old Jamaican Forward. He has offers from Belgium however West Ham are currently in talks with him. Meanwhile West Ham have revealed their season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will cost £289, with them having the cheapest pricing strategy in the Barclays Premier League.

The new Avengers: Age of Ultron movie has come out this week and James Haskell posted on Instagram an image of himself dressed up as the Iron Man character. He returned to the London Wasp's club, where he started his career, for the 2012 season. Haskell joined the Wasp's in 2002 and played eight seasons for the club, winning his first England cap in 2007. He then moved to France to play for Stade Francais, after the 2011 unsuccessful World Cup, he moved to Tokyo to play for the Ricoh Black Rams. After four months in Japan, he switched to New Zealand to play for the Highlanders, before returning to England in 2012.

The passage discusses an incident in which a married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were hit by an Amtrak train on Easter morning in Durham, North Carolina. The train was heading north from Charlotte to New York City, and the couple was hit on property owned by Norfolk-Southern. It is believed that the couple may have lived in a homeless camp, as they were seen by a witness asking for help crossing the railroad tracks with their grocery cart. None of the 166 passengers on the train were injured, although a man who fell ill during the delay did receive treatment. The Lowe's were pronounced dead at the scene. The train was delayed for about two hours and 45 minutes before continuing on its route.

The fate of the science of cloning may depend on the results of a new study into the health of four cloned sheep, Debbie, Denise, Diane, and Daisy. The four sheep, cloned from the same adult ewe as Dolly, the first cloned mammal, are being put through a battery of tests and assessments, including regular joint X-rays and full-body FMRI scans. The study aims to investigate the three most common co-morbidities associated with aging in sheep: cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. The results of the study, which could have profound implications for the future of cloning, will be published next week.

The Fault in Our Stars was the night's big winner, taking home best movie and Shailene Woodley winning best female performance, the Trailblazer Award and best kiss. Scarlett Johansson, Chris Evans, Chris Hemsworth, Mark Ruffalo and Jeremy Renner all took the stage to present Robert Downey Jr with the Generation Award.

Tulsa County reserve deputy Robert Bates, who has admitted to fatally shooting an unarmed man following a sting operation, has pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter. Bates, who was working as a volunteer deputy, was charged after he shot Eric Harris, 44, on April 2. Bates has said the shooting was accidental, that he meant to stun Harris with a Taser. He has since been allowed to go on vacation to the Bahamas. Members of Harris' family have spoken out about the killing, and have called into question why Bates, who is 73, was even on the force, the New York Daily News reports. The sheriff's office has said Bates was a friend of the sheriff and had donated large sums of money to the agency. Forged records made it appear that Bates was properly trained, the paper reports.

Bobbi Kristina Brown - who is in a rehab facility after being found face down in a bath - has 'global and irreversible brain damage', according to her grandmother Cissy Houston. She remains unresponsive, despite having come out of her medically induced coma, and has a tracheotomy, sources tell CNN. Brown's father, Bobby Brown, had previously said she was awake, watching him. An attorney for the Brown family said Bobbi Kristina will have a long life, but the quality of it is still to be determined.

The passage talks about how Bob Barker, the former long-time host of "The Price is Right," made a one-day return to the show on April 1, marking his first appearance on the program in over eight years.

A series of interesting stories that trended this week includes: 1) Four rainbows appeared across the sky in New York; 2) In China, it's becoming a common practice to hire exotic dancers for wakes; 3) A 102-year-old woman went back in time with the help of filmmakers; 4) A prom-posal referencing bombs was rejected by one school; and 5) Actor Ewan McGregor will play Lumiere in the Beauty and the Beast live-action remake.

University of Michigan is going to be screening the film American Sniper which has caused some controversy as some students objected to it. The film is about the most lethal sniper in US military history played by Bradley Cooper and the students felt that the movies depiction of the Iraq war reflected negatively on the middle east. However, the university decided it was in line with its values of freedom of expression and reversed its decision, which was supported by the head football coach Jim Harbaugh.

Several reports of tornadoes were made in Kansas and Missouri as storms passed through the area. There were also reports of hail the size of baseballs in Farmington. The National Weather Service has warned that more storms are expected tomorrow in the midwest, Mississippi River valley, Tennessee River valley, and near the southern great lakes.

Several reports of tornadoes were made in Kansas and Missouri on Wednesday night amid a line of severe storms that moved through the area, causing dangerous conditions. "Nighttime tornadoes are the most deadly, and the most dangerous", said Chad Myers, CNN severe weather expert. In addition to tornadoes, large hail was reported with these storms.

The number of heavy drinkers in the US rose 17.2% between 2005 and 2012, according to a study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, with most of the increases due to women, as social norms change. Binge drinking is defined for women as four or more drinks on a single occasion at least once in the past month, and for men, five or more. In 2012, 8% of Americans were considered heavy drinkers, and 18% were binge drinkers. The study was the first to track adult drinking patterns at a county level.

102 year old Alice Barker, a dancer from the 1930's and 1940's, was able to watch videos of herself dancing for the first time, alongside celebrities such as Frank Sinatra. Mark Cantor, from Jazz-on-Film, assembled a video of 'soundies', or music videos, from the era for her to watch.

A gray whale named Varvara has swam nearly 14,000 miles, a record for the longest migration of a mammal. The whale left Russia's Sakhalin Island and made her way to Baja, Mexico, stopping at three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales. This has caused scientists to reevaluate the differentiation between eastern and western gray whales.

Wildfires in Siberia have led to smoke and ash travelling across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest. This combination of smoke, wind and solar light is causing a deep red hue to sunrise and sunsets in the region.

The US is complaining to Moscow about a Russian fighter jet that flew close to a US plane earlier this week in an "unsafe and unprofessional" manner over the Baltic Sea. The Russian plane was flying towards the Russian border with its transponder switched off, according to Russian state news agency Sputnik. The US has complained about similar incidents in the past.

ISIS has released hundreds of Yazidis that were captured last summer in northern Iraq, including many women and children. Arab tribal leaders helped coordinate the release of the mostly women and children, along with the elderly and infirm. The Yazidis are considered to be devil worshipers by their Muslim neighbors, and ISIS has acted with particular cruelty to the group, killing hundreds and raping and enslaving female captives. It is not known why ISIS would release these groups of people.

Lady Antebellum's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway, but everyone on board was evacuated safely. Video of the incident shows smoke and flames pouring from the rear as traffic slowed. A passenger on another vehicle captured the footage and later noted that they did not know what to expect as they drew closer to the bus. The rear tire is reported to have blown out, causing the bus to burst into flames, which destroyed a back lounge, save Scott's Bible. The band is set to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards this Sunday.

The epic miniseries "Roots" is being remade for a new generation and will air in 2016, with the three networks A&E, Lifetime and History simulcasting the remake of the saga of Kunta Kinte, an African who was captured, shipped to America and sold into slavery. The original star, LeVar Burton, will co-executive produce the new miniseries -- dubbed "original" and "contemporary" -- which will largely draw from the original novel. Producers will also consult scholars for added authenticity.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an unmanned Dragon spacecraft from Cape Canaveral, Florida, but was unsuccessful in its attempt to land the rocket on a floating barge. The launch was the second attempt, as Monday's launch was scrubbed due to weather. The Dragon will dock with the International Space Station in a few days and deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including research equipment and an espresso maker for astronauts. After delivering the supplies, the Dragon will return to Earth carrying over 3,000 pounds of science experiments, trash, and other items.

Defense Minister Gen Nakatani has revealed that Japan's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered an extraterrestrial unidentified flying object. The information was disclosed in response to a query by flamboyant former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki. Inoki, who entered Japan's Upper House for a second stint in politics in 2013, is the founder of the New Japan Pro Wrestling organization, and is widely known in Japan for his colossal chin and once-ever-present red scarf. In 2007, then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba had also pondered the legal ramifications of defense against an invasion from outer space.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna beat Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene in a race, after training for a week. Rich and Anna are not married, and neither are Vytautas and Neringa. There were many different combinations of competitors, with Rich and Anna being the only ones to have a man carrying a woman. Rich and Anna will now compete in the World Championships in Finland in July.
An Englishman in Yorkshire is finally seeing results from the fruit plant he had been dubious about growing in South Yorkshire's climate.

The summary would be as follows:

RNLI crew, a medic, and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter were sent to Sker Beach to assist a rider with head injuries. She was treated for coldness and unconsciousness and then flown to the University Hospital of Wales.

Passage summary:
The fourteenth spy film in the James Bond series, A View to a Kill, was released in 1985 and starred Roger Moore as James Bond.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh while playing Scarlett O'Hara in the film, Gone With The Wind, has sold for $137,000 at auction.
The dress, which was slate blue-gray, has faded to light gray over the years.
It was one of more than 150 items sold at auction on Saturday in Beverly Hills, California from the Academy Award-winning film.
The dress was worn in several key scenes, including when Scarlett encountered Rhett Butler, played by Clark Gable.
Floppy disks are magnetic storage mediums encased in rectangular plastic carriers.

A group of Italian consumers' organisations has made a complaint against McDonald's for being allegedly unfair to its franchisees by forcing them to pay excessive rents and additional fees. Though McDonald's denies these allegations, stating that it works closely with its franchisees so they can have necessary support, and that this approach has been successful for many years; the complaint has been supported by the Service Employees International Union and European unions, including the Bakers Food and Allied Workers Union in the United Kingdom. The European Commission will study the submission, and if the allegations are found to be founded, it has the power to launch an investigation.

- Suspects attempted to carjack a man at a South Los Angeles gas station at 12:15am on Saturday.
- They failed and poured gasoline on the man's white Dodge Charger instead.
- Group set the car on fire as two passengers sat inside; they all escaped injury.
- The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as an arson.

Dayna Dobias, 19, suffers from cerebral palsy, but she's hoping to change the way people with disabilities are represented by television, film and fashion industries. The passage in question details the events of a court trial in which a local busker was accused of fraud. Angus Carpenter, a 62 year old man from Liverpool who has played in the city centre for more than 30 years, was found guilty of one of three counts of fraud. Specifically, the jury convicted him of one count of playing his bagpipes with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner draped on his instrument. For this count, Mr. Carpenter was found guilty. However, he was cleared of the two other counts by the jury. During the trial, Sgt Chris Gaynor testified that Carpenter gave the impression that he was collecting cash for the Hillsborough Justice Campaign. In his defense, Carpenter claimed that he had previously piped for the charity, but that on this occasion he was merely busking. The chairman of the Hillsborough Justice Campaign, Kenneth Derbyshire, stated that he had granted Carpenter permission to design and display a banner featuring the eternal flame and the word "justice," but denied him permission to collect funds for the charity. Carpenter confirmed in his trial that the banner was intended as a tribute to the victims, not as an attempt to deceive. He is to be sentenced in January.

Once the home of the nation's newspapers, Fleet Street's last two journalists have now left. Gill was a controversialist, a brilliant writer, and a kind man, and his sudden death has shocked everyone. He was diagnosed with cancer, the full English, last month. Despite this, he didn't feel cheated and felt lucky in his life. Gill was born in 1954, and started his writing career in the 1980s. He was known for dictating his copy over the telephone due to his dyslexia. He married author Cressida Connolly in 1983 and venture capitalist Amber Rudd in 1991, divorcing later. The tournament finishes on 29 May at the same stadium it started. Eight teams are taking part, with the top four sides qualifying for the play-offs. The competition is heats based, with each team facing each other twice. Fixtures, results and scores can be found at BBC Sport.

A crash between a tractor and a motorcycle on a Lincolnshire road has killed the motorcyclist. Police are appealing for witnesses of the collision to step forward.

The pound fell against the dollar as global economic worries affected investors. The currency has recently been recovering after falling to its lowest since January 2009. The UN has agreed to dedicate part of the radio spectrum to a global flight tracking system following the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 nearly two years ago. MH370 disappeared in March 2014 with 239 people on board; the current tracking system, which relies on ground-based radar, leaves 70% of the world's airspace uncovered. The new system, which will use satellites to track aircraft, is expected to be up and running within the next two years.

The Planning Inspectorate for Wales is holding an eight-day hearing on a request to build on 250 hectares of common land in Ebbw Vale. The passage describes an exhibition at the Museum of Liverpool called Growing Up in the City. BT customers in Scotland have lost nearly £200,000 in two weeks to fraudsters who have tricked them into revealing bank details. Once they have gained access to the victims' computers, they have been able to transfer money to their accounts. James Milner has announced his retirement from international football. The announcement comes days after England's shock 2-1 defeat to Iceland in the Euro 2016 round of 16. He won 61 caps for his country and was a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships.

US and Canadian police have arrested three people after border agents were fired upon while interrupting an alleged attempt to smuggle ecstasy from Canada to San Francisco.

The incident began when border agents encountered two men carrying backpacks near the border between Canada and the US. Officials said one of the men dropped his backpack, fired a weapon at the agents, and ran. The other man was taken into custody.

The backpacks belonging to both men contained a total of 58lb (26kg) of ecstasy, according to US border patrol agents.

Investigators later arrested a woman and her boyfriend, who they say planned to pick up the two men at the border. The woman had been monitoring police radio communications on a mobile phone, officials said.

Six contractors were exposed to low levels of naturally-occurring radioactive material while working on EnQuest's Thistle platform, 125 miles (201km) north-east of Shetland. The firm said the level of exposure was less than 1% of the legally reportable level. EnQuest said it had taken "additional precautionary steps" but the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) has not carried out an investigation. Evo Morales, the President of Bolivia, has signed new legislation into law that permits children to work from the age of 10, according to the country's vice-president. A new government form used for divorces in England and Wales has caused controversy among family lawyers.
