The passage describes an exhibition at the Museum of Liverpool called Growing Up in the City. The exhibition features 25 photographs that capture life for children in Liverpool over a period of 100+ years, from the 1880s to the 1990s. The photographs not only provide a snapshot of childhood but also serve as a thought-provoking social history of life in Liverpool across the decades. The curator of the exhibition, Kay Jones, says she chose images that stood out and told the story of childhood, including both positive and negative experiences. The exhibit runs until 25 September.

BT customers in Scotland have lost nearly £200,000 in two weeks to fraudsters who have tricked them into revealing bank details. Victims have been cold-called by people claiming to be from the telecoms company's technical department. Once they have gained access to the victims' computers, they have been able to transfer money to their accounts. Police are warning people never to give out any banking details or account numbers over the telephone.

James Milner has retired from international football, the England midfielder announced on Thursday. The 30-year-old, who won 61 caps after making his senior debut in 2009, was a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships but played just three minutes at Euro 2016. "The decision we've reached is about common sense. I wish Sam [Allardyce] and England success in the future," Milner said.

James Milner has announced his retirement from international football. The announcement comes days after England's shock 2-1 defeat to Iceland in the Euro 2016 round of 16. He won 61 caps for his country and was a squad member at two World Cups and two European Championships.

The Nevada Athletic Commission, which sanctioned the bout, received a request from McGregor on Wednesday to use 8oz gloves.
The NAC will debate the matter publicly on 16 August as its rules state fights at 154lbs require 10oz gloves.
The undefeated fighter previously posted on Instagram that he would wear 8oz Grant gloves.
The fight between McGregor and Mayweather could be the richest in history.

The 34 year old defendant Davina, real name David Ayrton, is charged with raping a 15 year old girl in a garage in 2004. The defendant, who has learning difficulties, denied the charge and will be sentenced on March 4th. There is substantial grounds to believe she would be a risk to herself and fail to appear in court, thus she was remanded in custody pending sentencing at a male prison in Winchester. The jury heard that Ayrton attempted suicide last summer, and in 2014 confessed to a care worker about the attack.

The 13 letters that once lit Yankee Stadium in the Bronx failed to find a buyer at auction Wednesday.
They were expected to go for between $300,000 and $600,000.
The current owner, Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, wants 'a new generation to own and enjoy this icon'
The letters are 10-feet-tall and 10-feet-wide. Jackson bought them after the stadium's final game in 2008.

US and Canadian police have arrested three people after border agents were fired upon while interrupting an alleged attempt to smuggle ecstasy from Canada to San Francisco.

The incident began when border agents encountered two men carrying backpacks near the border between Canada and the US. Officials said one of the men dropped his backpack, fired a weapon at the agents, and ran. The other man was taken into custody.

The backpacks belonging to both men contained a total of 58lb (26kg) of ecstasy, according to US border patrol agents.

Investigators later arrested a woman and her boyfriend, who they say planned to pick up the two men at the border. The woman had been monitoring police radio communications on a mobile phone, officials said.

Six contractors were exposed to low levels of naturally-occurring radioactive material while working on EnQuest's Thistle platform, 125 miles (201km) north-east of Shetland. The firm said the level of exposure was less than 1% of the legally reportable level. EnQuest said it had taken "additional precautionary steps" but the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) has not carried out an investigation. The contractors, employed by Wood Group, had been removing a piece of pipework. Their employer said it had reinforced safety procedures. The men had not been wearing personal protective equipment as it was assumed the area was clear.
A car crash has happened on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness, causing injuries to several people. The road is closed, and police are currently conducting investigations.

Evo Morales, the President of Bolivia, has signed new legislation into law that permits children to work from the age of 10, according to the country's vice-president. The law allows those aged 10 to 14 to work in industries including manufacturing, construction and commerce for up to six hours a day and 40 hours a week, provided they are not working at night, do not work on Sundays and do not perform jobs deemed too dangerous. The legislation also permits 12-year-olds to work for others, provided they have parental authorisation. The vice-president, Alvaro Garcia Linera, said the law reflected the needs of one of the poorest countries in South America. It sets harsher punishments for violence against children and mandates a 30-year prison sentence for child homicide.
Council leadership has seen three senior figures take voluntary redundancy amid claims of further departures among senior staff.

An earthquake struck near Lucca, Italy. The magnitude-4.8 quake was felt as far away as Milan and Florence. The epicentre was in Garfagnana. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage, but phone lines were down and power supplies were cut in the Garfagnana area. As a precaution, schools were evacuated and were to be checked for any damage. The earthquake was described as "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow". This comes as Italy is still trying to recover from the deadly earthquake in L'Aquila in 2009, where almost 300 people died.

The man accused of killing neighbour Terrence Freebody had declining mental capacity and was also an alcoholic, a jury has been told.
71-year-old Luigi Costa has been charged with killing Freebody at Mugga Way in the Canberra suburb of Red Hill in July 2012.
Professor Paul Mullen told the court that Costa's calls to emergency services indicated his changing mood, while faeces found by police indicated his confused mental state.
Prosecutor Shane Drumgold said Costa was likely suffering from dementia, but defence counsel denied this.

- Bridgwater Community Hospital will be partly funded by a £330m investment from the coalition for new NHS buildings in England.
- It will cost £33m in total and NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust will pay the remaining balance.
- The new hospital will have 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit and X-ray as well as space for mobile scanners.
- It will replace the current hospital built in 1813, which has become outdated and cramped.
- Work on the hospital is hoped to be finished by autumn 2014, providing that planning permission is granted on the land at Bowers Lane.

The agri-food marketing body will support the Northern Ireland's agri-food industry by providing strategic leadership and direction for the marketing activities of both government and private sector organisations. The body, which will be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board, will be similar to the already successful Scotland Food and Drink. 

It was announced by Arlene Foster, DETI Minister, who welcomed the announcement, as did Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill, who nonetheless flagged potential implications for other organisations.

OneWeb - a "truly global" company with company registration in the UK's Channel Islands - is aiming to deliver broadband links from orbit to every corner of the globe, with a particular focus on connecting every school. The company is doing this through a constellation of at least 600 spacecraft which will comprise the greatest rocket campaign in the history of spaceflight, with more than 20 Soyuz vehicles booked to throw clusters of 32-36 satellites into orbit. The first 10 satellites are scheduled to launch in April next year, with another batch following in November, and the roll-out completed by the middle of the decade. However, the company is not alone in its ambitions - SpaceX, Boeing, and ViaSat are also planning similar projects. The success of the projects will depend on the companies' ability to secure the multi-billion dollar financing required.

A new government form used for divorces in England and Wales has caused controversy among family lawyers. The form, which can be completed without legal advice, leaves a space to name someone committing adultery with the petitioner's spouse. Lawyers say that usually the third party isn't named as it increases conflict, and there's no need. But the box is there, so it will likely be filled in. The person named on the form will be sent copies of the paperwork and a chance to respond; they could delay proceedings and make them cost more.

The passage discusses a speed camera that is pointed directly at a house's front door,  after being angled in the opposite direction for two years. The camera was one of many that were switched off, and in its place, speed enforcement operations have been carried out. The mystery surrounding who repositioned the camera remains, and it could be removed completely.

The passage in question discusses how The Sun called out the comedian, Russell Brand, on hypocrisy after he was outside the prime minister's Downing Street home supporting a campaign by residents of an east London estate who fear they will be turfed out of their homes to allow richer renters to move in. Brand is accused of being a hypocrite because he campaigns for economic and political "revolution" to help poorer people, yet he lives in a luxury home. Brand called the Channel 4 News journalist who asked him about his accommodation a "snide" and refused to answer the question. Brand has been condemned as a hypocrite plenty of times before, and he has explained it in the past by saying that he is aware of the inevitability of such a charge, and that he believes in change, personal change most of all.
Police in Ashbourne arrested a man in his late 40s after finding an elaborate grow house containing plants in a warehouse.

The passage describes a social media campaign supporting a 13 year old boy who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. The campaign began as a hashtag on Facebook and Instagram, and has since gone viral, with a mystery donor paying for a billboard in Holywood. The boy's family has received lots of support from people all over the world.

The passage discusses the state of poverty in 2011, specifically the poverty rate and the median income of American households. The poverty rate remained steady at 15% after three previous years of increases, while the median household income decreased by 1.5%. Additionally, income inequality increased by 1.6% in 2011, and the percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased slightly.

Melania Trump has said she will not immediately move her 10-year-old son Barron to the White House, instead allowing him to finish the school year in New York. But while some have criticised the decision, others have supported it, saying it is what responsible parents do. It is not the first time a child has not lived at the White House - though all three of the Obama girls did from the day of their father's inauguration. Historians say it has happened before, with some first ladies taking a less prominent role. But what is the White House really like for a child to grow up in? Chelsea Clinton did her homework in the Oval Office and hosted sleepovers there, while the Obamas eat dinner together every night.

Last year £3.6bn was spent on agency staff, the regulator wants that reduced by £1bn by the end of this financial year. A cap was introduced in October which has saved £600m so far. The aim was to reduce the overall cost of agency staff as well as getting hospitals to rely less on them, as they are more expensive. The NHS is currently 10% short on its goal and it's not clear if spending has risen in other areas.

The actress behind Hermione in the Harry Potter films, Emma Watson, will play Belle in the upcoming Disney remake of Beauty and the Beast. It will be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. Dan Stevens, who starred in Downton Abbey, will play the Beast and Luke Evans co-stars as villain Gaston.

The movie, which begins filming in May, has signed some big names: Emma Watson will play Belle, Dan Stevens is the Beast, and Kevin Kline will play Maurice. It will be released in US cinemas on March 17 2017.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan. The purchase will not affect the workers' alternative pension scheme, as had been feared. The new owner intends to restore the company to its former profitability by investing more money into the business and cutting costs.

Open AI is a venture backed by Amazon Web Services, Infosys, Paypal co-founder Peter Thiel, and Tesla Motors/SpaceX CEO Elon Musk. Open AI's purpose is to "advance digital intelligence in the way that is most likely to benefit humanity as a whole, unconstrained by a need to generate financial return", of which only a tiny fraction of the $1bn pledged will be spent in the next few years. Elon Musk has publicly stated that AI is humanity's biggest existential threat.
A man has been shot dead in a Sheffield street today. A number of other shootings have taken place in the area in recent weeks.

Following a meeting with the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee, Brexit Secretary, David Davis, announced that the UK government will share information on a monthly basis with Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. In order to create a "two-way information flow", each nation will be able to voice their opinions on the talks between the Westminster government and Brussels. The Scottish government hopes to have greater transparency on the UK's intentions, particularly concerning market access.

The passage discusses a new facility to be built in Kilmarnock that will house primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. The council plans to name the campus after the renowned writer William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock and was passionate about education. McIlvanney began as an English teacher but changed careers to write full-time, earning immediate recognition with the publication of his first novel, Remedy Is None. He went on to write a number of Glasgow-based works and earned the title of "Godfather of Tartan Noir." He was also an influential poet, journalist, and broadcaster.

Doncaster Rovers drew 0-0 with Fleetwood Town in a League One match. With neither team having anything to play for, it was perhaps unsurprising that the goalless draw wasn't a high-quality affair. In fact, Doncaster's media team struggled to put together match highlights, eventually releasing a 27-second video which comprised just 14 seconds of action.

- The luxury interior has been built inside a customised Boeing 747-8.
- It boasts a master bedroom, multiple lounges and even an on-board restaurant.
- There's also a large dining room, a conference room and an 'aeroloft' sleeping area on the top deck.
- It even has a 'state room' for when its owner wants to relax in style.
- The jumbo jet reportedly cost its mystery owner a whopping £400million.

Confor, a forestry promotion agency, has warned that 40,000 acres of commercial forest in Wales have been lost since 2001. Successive Welsh ministers have emphasised the growth of native, broadleaf tree species instead, which has led to the loss of commercially grown trees. Confor claims that the current system for creating new woodland areas is too bureaucratic. However, the Welsh government aims to balance environmental, economic, and social growth in the development of its forests.

The passage discusses a plan to transfer power over planning decisions from a central agency to local councils in Northern Ireland. The move has been met with both support and opposition. Supporters argue that the change would democratize the planning process, while opponents warn of potential discrimination and the need for increased transparency. The debate over the transfer of power also highlights the issue of political donations and the potential for close relationships between developers and political parties.

A tonne of plastic detergent bottles have washed up on a Cornish beach, prompting concerns from conservationists. The National Trust, which owns the beach, said it believed a container went overboard from a ship during stormy weather. Cornwall Wildlife Trust said it was concerned about the impact on "sensitive marine life". The bottles are sealed but some have leaked. The public is advised to keep children and dogs away. 
The BBC has contacted the detergent company but has not received a comment.

Thierry Henry has questioned whether Arsenal can win the Premier League with Olivier Giroud as their main striker.
The former Gunner believes the club need to buy a goalkeeper, centre half, defensive midfielder and striker in the summer.
Henry, speaking as a Sky Sports pundit after Arsenal's 0-0 draw with Chelsea, said: 'You had the best example with Chelsea today. They were struggling last season to win the league. They went on to buy Thibaut Cortouis, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas and Diego Costa - and you saw it today, a team didn't and a team did.'
Arsenal are third in the Premier League, level on points with Manchester City but with a game in hand.
The New Orleans Pelicans are a member club of the NBA's Western Conference Southwest Division.

Embarrassing footage has captured the moment a Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover in front of hundreds of tourists.
The unidentified soldier was taking up position in his sentry box during the Changing of the Guard when the incident happened.
He lost his footing and slid sideways, knocking his bearskin on the side of the box and dropping his rifle.
The young guard quickly scrambled to his feet as his colleagues marched past as if nothing had happened - but he started to blush as he peered at the crowd.

The passage is about the iPhone and the impact it has on the digital age. The iPhone was not the first phone with a camera, nor was it the first to allow internet browsing or email - but it popularised these functions by making them easy to use. Consequently, iPhones (and other smartphones) have become the most ubiquitous cameras, transforming photography - and the same is true of internet use. The passage recalls the launch of the iPhone and the author's experience then - and reflects on how iPhone has come to transform the world, for better or worse.

Anzac Day services were held at Westminster Abbey and Hyde Park Corner on Monday morning to commemorate the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during WW1. 

Around 400 people took part in a parade at the Cenotaph and laid wreaths prior to the dawn service. 

Addressing the crowds, Alexander Downer, the Australian high commissioner to the UK, said: "We consider the enthusiasm, the courage, and the heroism of the Anzac troops - ordinary men fighting for God, King and empire, for their mates, for adventure, for a world without war.

Just 2,191 compensation applications were approved in the year after the fiasco making a total payout of £203,066.
Ministers rejected a demand for blanket refunds saying it would 'create a precedent'.
Managers at the Passport Office received £1.8 million in bonuses with the highest single payment being £3,500.

The passage discusses a development plan for Bournemouth's East Cliff area, which involves the demolition of three Victorian hotels to make way for a six-story hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. The plan was approved by a majority of councillors, who argued that it would help tourism and improve living for older people in the town. However, English Heritage and some local residents opposed the plan, arguing that it would cause severe harm to the conservation area and destroy the historic character of the area. The debate over the plan highlights the tension between the need for development and the need to preserve the historic character of a protected conservation area.
Tim Roth is an English actor and director, born May 14, 1961.
Timothy Simon Roth is an English actor and director. Tim Roth was born in 1975 and is the guitarist for the Canadian metal band, Into Eternity.

Tom Baker, an English actor, is renowned for his role as the fourth Doctor in the science fiction series Doctor Who, a part he played for the longest time of any actor. He also narrated the comedy series Little Britain and performed voice work for other commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.
Tom Baker, a English actor, has performed acting roles, narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.
Tool is a band that has won three Grammy awards, topped charts worldwide, and toured internationally.

Topman is a UK based men's clothing store with locations across the UK and Ireland. It is owned by the Arcadia Group, which also owns popular UK brands Burton, Miss Selfridge, Wallis, Evans, and Dorothy Perkins.

Horse racing commentator Cornelius Lysaght praises Gosden's tactics in preparing Shutter Speed for the Musidora, and comments on how the going (ground conditions) were in the favour of the victorious filly. Lysaght also notes that the trainer will walk the course before deciding whether his colt Cracksman runs in the Derby trial, the Dante Stakes, sixteen days before the Derby itself. John Gosden explains that the ground was very soft and that Shutter Speed will be a better horse on better going. He also indicates that he will rely on Enable and Coronet in the Epsom Oaks as Shutter Speed goes to France's Chantilly race.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf and the RMT union have ended a dispute over pay for seafarers on two freight boats. The two freight vessels, Hellier and Hildasay, will return to operator Serco Northlink next month after a contracted out service with Seatruck. Serco Northlink had offered to bridge the pay gap for workers but this was declined by Seatruck. The new charter arrangements will mean that crew members will be paid at least the minimum wage.

Trevor Deely, a 22 year old banking worker, has been missing since December 2000. Recent developments in the case include an excavation of a 3 acre woodland site in Dublin, and a public appeal for a man seen talking to Deely in CCTV footage to come forward.

Castleford fought back from 26 points down but lost after Mellor exploited their indecision on a short kick-off to race clear for Widnes. The Tigers had looked set to complete a dramatic comeback when Flynn scored to set up a tense finish, but they ultimately suffered their fourth successive Super League defeat.
Trollhunters is an American fantasy TV series produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You, with Guillermo del Toro as creator for Netflix.

Moroccan FA chief Fouzi Lekjaa is quoted as saying "We are preparing for a future full of good things for both Africa and Morocco". This follows the nation's readmission to the African Football Confederation after being banned for refusing to host the 2015 African Cup of Nations. Morocco's place at the 2015 tournament was taken by Equatorial Guinea, who went on to win after beating Tunisia in the quarter-finals. This outcome led to a row between the Tunisian federation and the African football ruling body, which threatened Tunisia's participation in the 2017 tournament. This row was ended after a meeting between Tunisian officials and CAF president Issa Hayatou.

Moroccan FA chief Fouzi Lekjaa says Morocco are back after being banned from the 2015 Nations Cup for refusing to host the tournament due to Ebola fears.
However, the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned the ruling and reduced the fine from $1m to $50,000.
Tunisia also faced expulsion from the 2017 Nations Cup for a row with Caf, but managed to smooth things over.

Serena Williams conceded her French Open preparations had suffered a setback after an 'eye-opening' struggle against Sara Errani.
The world number one beat the Italian 4-6 7-6 3-6 but Williams was far from impressed with her display.
Williams and Alison Riske were thrashed 6-0 6-3 in the doubles rubber by Errani and Flavia Pennetta.
US were beaten 3-2 by Italy and will now face a play-off to remain in World Group.
A police Facebook post has appealed to parents to know where their children are after two cars were damaged in the latest in a series of attacks in Newry.

The passage outlines the spending of the major political parties during the 2014 EU elections. UKIP came first in the elections and also spent the most money on its campaign, spending £68 per vote. The Labour party came second in the elections and spent the second most on its campaign, spending £26 per vote. The Conservative party was third and spent 79p per vote. The results of the other parties are not mentioned in the text.

The film `Underdog` was directed by Frederik Du Chau 
The film's script was written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. 
The movie stars Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, with voice work from Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The University of Mississippi is a mostly locally attended university, with 60% of its population coming from Mississippi, and 55% of undergraduates. 23% of the university is made of up minorities, and students come from 90 different nations around the world.

Six-time Olympic gold medallist Usain Bolt will compete for Jamaica in the 2014 IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2-3. Bolt says he is "fit, healthy and ready to run" and that "Jamaica has a long and successful tradition in relays and when we put on the national colours we always do our best to make the country proud.
Valencia is the third largest city in Spain, with around 800,000 inhabitants in the administrative centre, and a population of 1.7 to 2.5 million in the metropolitan area.

The movie Vedam, directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi, stars Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham. It is a Telugu language Indian drama film.

The passage describes two Indian Tamil films, Veeram (2014) and Veeram (2016). Both films are directed by Siva and Jayaraj respectively, with Vijaya Productions serving as producer for the former. The former film described is an action film, while the latter's genre is historical drama.
The passage talks about Veeru Devgan, who is an Indian stunt and action choreographer and a film director in Bollywood.

The passage discusses Vietnam, a country in eastern Indochina. With an estimated 92.7 million inhabitants, it is the world's 14th most populous country, and the 9th most populous Asian country. It borders China to the north, Laos to the northwest, Cambodia to the southwest, Thailand across the Gulf of Thailand to the southwest, and the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia across the South China Sea to the east and southeast. Since 2000, Vietnam's economic growth rate has been highly positive, and in 2011 it had the highest Global Growth Generators Index of 11 major economies. The country is officially known as the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, and is one of the last remaining communist states in the world.

The HebCelt festival, taking place on the Isle of Lewis from the 19th-22nd of July, will offer an augmented reality experience to festival goers, allowing them to access information and interviews with artists, as well as giving people around the world the chance to interact with the festival.

The HebCelt Festival this year will have an augmented reality experience; visitors can use an app for smartphones and tablets to unlock online information--such as videos and band interviews--available instantly any time.

Wales underwent rapid industrialization and a demographic expansion during the Industrial Revolution due to the development of mining and metallurgical industries, most notably the South Wales Coalfield.

The passage describes intensified attacks on Aleppo, with a trauma hospital once again being hit. The US has suspended talks with Russia, blaming them for the attacks, to which Russia has responded with a regretful statement and accusation of the US shifting blame. The US has also stated that Russia and Syria are pursuing a military course, targeting critical infrastructure and preventing humanitarian aid from reaching those in need. This comes after US personnel were withdrawn from Geneva where the two countries were to co-ordinate air strikes against jihadist groups.

The passage is about an interactive video that doesn't work on older browsers, where Robert Opie, the founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging, and Advertising, discusses why we change what we buy and how ownership and ranking of big brands in the UK is changing. You can find a non-interactive version of the video and extra information linked in the passage.
The passage discusses the injury suffered by Webb and his expected return date. It also covers the fact that he has renewed his contract with Wales and the Ospreys.
Weekly Idol is a comedy rap show hosted by rapper Defconn and comedian Jeong Hyeong-don.
The passage talks about Wells (a 23 year old) and his performance (373 runs) in  the T20 Blast last season.  In addition, Wells spoke about the club's environment and the coaches.

England manager Gareth Southgate's chances of getting the job on a permanent have been boosted by the 0-0 draw with Slovenia. Arsene Wenger, whose club contract also runs until the summer, has been linked with the England job but said Southgate "has accumulated experiences and is a good observer". Wenger believes the most important thing is the person's competency, and that Southgate has a good opportunity to show he has the quality for the role.
Wildfang is a women's apparel company catering to the tomboy look.

Bill Clinton, the 42nd President of the United States (1993-2001) was born on August 19, 1946.  His first inauguration took place on January 20, 1993, on the West Front of the United States Capitol Building in Washington, D.C.

Barry Wilson has been without a club since being released by Championship side Forest in May. The 30-year-old rejoined Forest in August 2013, having previously spent four seasons at the club before signing for Celtic. He has also previously played for Preston North End and Notts County.
The passage is about the novel Winter's Tale, written by Mark Helprin in 1983.

The study found that women are as likely to ask for a pay rise as men, but are less likely to receive a pay rise. When comparing like-for-like male and female workers, men were 25% more likely to receive a pay rise when they asked. The study did not support the theory that women were less likely to ask for a pay rise because they were more wary of upsetting their boss or conforming to a female stereotype. The study did find that women and men under 40 both received and asked for pay rises to the same degree, which the researchers said could mean that negotiating behaviour is changing.
The album has sold more than 27 million copies worldwide as of October 2016.

Defence is a low priority for most political parties in the election; for the most part, the parties are not being forthcoming about their defence policies in their manifestos. 
The UK has been reducing its armed forces; for example, the size of the UK's regular army is being reduced from 102,000 to 82,000. 
The UK now spends less on defence than the likes of Russia and China.
There has been an absence of a commitment to spend 2% of GDP on defence.
It is likely that the UK will have to make further cuts in defence spending over the next few years; most political parties do not seem to be committing to ring-fencing defence spending.
The nuclear deterrent, aircraft carriers, and the military's conventional forces are all at risk of cuts in the near future.
YouTube is a giant in the digital world- the second most popular site in the world featuring video sharing. It is headquartered in California's San Bruno.
Bad Romance is a song from American singer Lady Gaga’s third extended play, The Fame Monster, released in 2009 and achieved worldwide success. Les Mauvais Romans is a 2011 independent drama film.
The passage talks about `` Hourglass '', a song from the 14th album of the same name by James Taylor, which is also the moniker of a British electronic duo.
" Roar" is a song from American singer Katy Perry's 2013 album, Prism. It was released as the lead single from the album on August 10, 2013.

The passage talks about Selena Gomez, an American singer who released her second solo album, "Revival," in 2015. This album peaked at #1 on the Billboard 200, while three of its singles reached the top of the Mainstream Top 40 chart in the US.

A 13 year old boy, Marcus, and his 9 year old sister, Aaliyah, were trapped in their home after a fire broke out on the first floor. Marcus called 911 and gave the dispatcher instructions on how to get into the home and where they were located. The dispatcher stayed on the line and coached Marcus on how to keep himself and his sister calm. Firefighters were able to locate the siblings and bring them to safety. They were both taken to the hospital with non-life threatening injuries.

A fire in a beach-side apartment complex (which was inhabited between May and November) in Westhampton Beach, New York, has been extinguished, leaving 90 condos destroyed.

Firefighters were unable to combat the flames indoors, due to the intensity of the fire, and instead had to use cranes to pour water onto the fire from above. 

The fire is thought to have started near a car park and melted the paint off nearby buildings. Currently, the cause of the fire is unknown and is being investigated.

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle is on a mission to change the way people think about the word 'fat'.
The New Jersey dancer, who weighs 240lbs, says 'fat' is just another honest description of what she is, and it shouldn't be used as an insult.
During a recent Ted talk, she explained that the more we are exposed to different body types, the more we accept them.
Lillian believes that by performing burlesque - which showcases her 'fat' body in a positive light - she is helping to change people's perceptions.
The response to her talk, which was given in 2014 but only posted on YouTube three weeks ago, has been mostly positive.

Harley Renshaw, now five, was diagnosed with cancer of the specialised nerve cells that form the nervous system - neuroblastoma - when he was four. He was diagnosed following a visit to the doctor due to a pain in his stomach. After 80 days of intensive chemotherapy and an operation to remove his kidney tumour, he returned home for his fifth birthday. He then had a stem cell transplant and weeks of radiotherapy. Now, Harley has been given the all-clear by doctors and will undergo regular check-ups to ensure the cancer has not returned. Neuroblastoma is one of the most common solid tumours in childhood and fewer than 100 children in the UK are diagnosed each year.

A Florida mother is fighting a school's attempt to suspend her five-year-old autistic son for wearing essential oils to help with his condition, saying the products help keep him calm and focused.  Jessica Kemp says teachers at Seminole County Elementary threatened to remove her son, Logan, from class because the oils manufactured by Doterra smell and are a distraction to other students, but Kemp says the oils have a positive impact on her son, and she will continue to fight the school's decision.

Robert Dellinger told investigators he was trying to kill himself when he crashed at 100mph.
The crash killed 24-year-old Amanda Murphy, eight months pregnant, and her fiance Jason Timmons, 29.
Dellinger told the court he 'has never been suicidal' and has led a 'productive and exemplary life'
The former executive at PGG Industries Inc said he has been plagued with serious health problems.

Police in Albury, Australia posted photos on Facebook in an attempt to find the owner of a lost iPhone. The photos featured police officers at the station taking 'selfies' and photos of the phone in various locations around the station. The phone was lost by Bella Crook at a friend's birthday party the night before, and was handed into the police station by a security guard. The Facebook posts by the police were shared many times by Crook's friends who praised the police department's creative attempt at reaching out to the phone's owner.

Nina Moric, 38, posted photos of heavy bruising on her arms to her Instagram account after Italian media reported that she had tried to commit suicide. Ms Moric denied the claims saying she had collapsed due to low blood pressure. Italian media had previously reported that in 2009 she had tried to kill herself by taking an overdose. Ms Moric was married to famous Italian paparazzi photographer Fabrizio Corona, who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities with compromising photographs.

A baby boy was found dead in a bag floating in a pond in 1988. Police recently re-opened the case as they were unable to identify the boy's mother. Following a review of the case, the baby's body was exhumed and DNA samples taken from his leg bone were put through the national police database, which led to a match being found for the baby's mother. The woman, who has not been named, was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but the charge was dropped with police satisfied that there was no foul play. The woman has been bailed with police continuing to investigate whether she should be charged with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial.

Hannah and Alex, a New Zealand couple, have created a solar-powered, wood and steel home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck. The couple undertook the year-and-a-half long project after returning to New Zealand from the UK without the funds to buy property. The self-sufficient home has two bedrooms, a wood-fired stove, and is surrounded by nature, and cost the couple approximately $25,000.

Star bygrave was diagnosed with a life-threatening liver condition, biliary atresia, shortly after birth, which causes bile ducts to be blocked or absent and requires surgery.
Her mother, Jade Reader, and father, Matthew Bygrave, both volunteered for surgery to unclog the ducts but were told they weren't suitable candidates for a partial liver transplant.
Star's maternal aunt, Shanell Reader, offered part of her liver and saved the infant's life.
Star underwent the operation in November and has since recovered well. She will have to have blood tests and liver function tests every week but can live a normal life.

Pit crew member Todd Phillips was injured Sunday when he was hit by the car of Francesco Dracone. Dracone had come in for tires and fuel on lap 25 when he spun exiting his pit box and clipped Phillips' leg. Phillips received stitches for a leg injury at the infield care center and was released.

Passage: Witness Robert Kushner lost his job as a basketball coach after testifying in a police corruption trial this week. Kushner testified that officers arrested him in 2007 for stealing $81,000 in cash and 7 lbs of marijuana from him, and that his charges were expunged eight years later as part of his probationary sentence. He pleaded guilty to driving under the influence in 2008 and was sentenced to 4 years of probation after being arrested again in 2011. Kushner had previously passed a background check and was hired to coach basketball in 2010, but school officials were unaware of his testimony this week. Lawyers for the former drug squad officers accused of racketeering have described the case as being based on lying drug dealers.

Police crime commissioner (PCC) Vera Baird faces investigation by the Ministry of Justice after she awarded £500,000 of taxpayers' money to a charity she runs alongside the force's chief constable. Baird donated the money to Victims First Northumbria - of which she is a director - which supports local crime victims. Sitting alongside her at the top of the organisation is chief constable Sue Sim. Critics have accused the pair of creating a "soap opera" within the force.

Two French tourists were questioned and filmed after an incident with a Quokka, in which they were seen to ignite an aerosol spray with a lighter, causing a large flame to make contact with the Quokka. The animal survived but was singed by the flame, and the two men (aged 18 and 24) were evicted from the island. They were charged with animal cruelty and will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17th.

The Omura's whale is a rare species of whale, that was feared to be extinct, has been found washed up on a Western Australian beach.
The discovery, only the second in Australia, is yet to be positively identified, due to the rarity of the find.
The 5.68m juvenile female whale, was confirmed to be an Omura's whale via DNA profiling, by Department of Parks and Wildlife staff.
Omura's whales are usually found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines and the Sea of Japan.

A taxi driver jumped to the conclusion that his passenger wasn't going to pay his fare, and took the man back to the taxi rank.
The man objected, and the driver continued driving for nearly a mile before the passenger jumped from the moving car.
The man suffered devastating brain injuries, and the judge ruled that the driver had imprisoned his passenger, giving the man the right to compensation.

The text describes a three-bedroom apartment in Egerton Place, Knightsbridge, London, that has been put up for sale for £575,000, three years before the lease runs out. The flat needs to be modernised, but could be worth upwards of £6 million if the buyer decides to extend the lease. The flat is one of two being sold with short leases, and the other, larger property is on the market for £595,000. The next cheapest three-bedroom property in Knightsbridge costs £1.5 million and this flat is only offered with a 28-year lease. The properties were built in 1893 and the first occupant of number 2 was Sir Henry Fielding Dickens, QC, son of the novelist Charles.

A wide-leg trouser is an emerging trend for SS15; it offers a viable alternative to the perennial skinny jean. The wide-leg is making a strong comeback, having first emerged as a trend in the 1970s, and has been seen on the catwalk for SS15 by Gucci, Celine and Stella McCartney. Wide-leg trousers are high-waisted and elongate the leg by several inches, thus making the wearer's legs look longer. Team with a simple shirt, knit or tee to keep the look current and the top half simple, to offset the volume of the trousers. Denim is considered the easiest way to currently nail the trend.

A woman has been arrested for breaking into a Martha's Vineyard home and selling the owners' belongings in a yard sale. Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, has been charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Items missing from the home include; four deck chairs, a weber grill, two side tables, one ann chase lamp, two lamps, two framed posters, various pots, pans, and linens, and a painting. The police are asking that anyone who received items from the home, return them.

Algae is blooming on the east coast of Australia, causing a fluorescent blue glow across the coastline. The incredible sight, captured by photographer Andy Hutchinson, is caused by millions of plankton called noctiluca scintillans, which is a single-celled phytoplankton that normally occurs due to natural causes, says oceanography expert Iain Suthers.

Phillip Pama, 28, has been charged with manslaughter after an argument with his neighbour, Leon Yeaman, 55, over noise levels. Phillip hit Mr. Yeaman, who was later pronounced dead. Phillip worked night shifts and the noise was disturbing his sleep. When confronted by Mr. Pama, Mr. Yeaman refused to turn his music down and Phillip 'blindly' hit him.

Shaun Andrew Mckerry, 31, tried to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores, County Durham, on March 15 brandishing an axe. Owner Sab Dhillon, and his wife Sam, jumped on Mckerry, with Mrs Dhillon hitting him twice with a baseball bat. Blood can be seen coming from Mckerry's nose in footage of the incident, and he was arrested minutes later by police. He had earlier pleaded guilty to attempted robbery and was jailed for six years at Durham Crown Court. Mckerry, from Coundon, earned his nickname in the 1990s because he kept returning home after committing a crime.

Carlos Toro came to the US, after providing information about his former bosses and associates from the Medellin Cartel, and began working for the DEA. In exchange for his help, Toro was promised citizenship. Toro is now facing deportation despite not having been paid for his work, and the DEA refusing to help him with his citizenship. He remains in limbo while trying to get a green card or passport.

Carlos Toro, who worked for the DEA for 27 years, is facing deportation despite promises of US citizenship. Toro worked as a mid-level member of the Medellin cartel in Colombia before fleeing the country. He helped take down several of his former bosses and associates before coming to the US. He began working for the DEA afterwards. Despite his contributions, including helping take down Manuel Noriega, the DEA will not help Toro with his citizenship. He remains in the US illegally as his visa expired on January 1.

An unnamed boyfriend makes his girlfriend, Saskia, take a test about his favorite football club, Arsenal FC. She scores an impressive 87%, but he still tells her she could have done better. As a result, he does not break up with her.

Agent Arthur Baldwin has been charged with attempted burglary and destruction of property after an off-duty arrest.  The Secret Service has revoked his security clearance and put him on leave following his arrest, two days after his supervisor was also put on leave after being accused of misconduct. Both matters are under investigation by the Homeland Security Department's inspector general.

Elena Curtin (23) from Portland, Oregon will not be prosecuted after she attacked her boyfriend’s ex with a crowbar whilst seven months pregnant. Curtin’s boyfriend’s ex was using heroin in her bathroom, and refused to leave; under Oregon law, physical force is allowed to be used against an intruder in this context. The ex had previously “harassed and threatened” Curtin during the two years leading up to the incident, and had attempted to re-ignite her boyfriend’s heroin addiction.

Kate and William, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, are expecting their second child. The British public favour the name Diana if the baby is a girl, with Alice and Charlotte as the next most popular names. If the baby is a boy, James is the most popular name, followed by Alexander. William has decided to take six weeks paternity leave from his job as a pilot to care for the couple's new addition. Most Brits are supportive of this decision.

Golfing legend Jack Nicklaus, aged 75, achieves his first hole-in-one at Augusta National, during the par-3 contest ahead of the Masters. Nicklaus's ball landed beyond the flag and spun back into the hole on the 130-yard fourth. It was one of five hole-in-ones during the day, including one by Camilo Villegas, who also scored another on the eighth. It wasn't enough for the Colombian to win, however, as he lost out to world no 74 Kevin Streelman in a play-off.

Once-coveted Tibetan Mastiffs can weigh 80kg and have plummeted in value over the past year; the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown is the main reason, as wealthy businessmen who previously would give the dogs to officials as gifts are now afraid to do so. The dogs are now being sent to slaughterhouses, with their meat sold as a cheap alternative to beef in restaurants. A property developer paid £1.2 million for a one-year-old golden-haired Tibetan Mastiff last year, thought to be the highest price ever paid for a dog.

Once-coveted Tibetan Mastiffs can weigh 80kg and have plummeted in value over the past year; the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown is the main reason, as wealthy businessmen who bought the dogs to give to officials as gifts have been caught and jailed, and officials themselves are under pressure to not accept gifts; the dogs are now being sent to slaughterhouses, as their meat is considered a delicacy in China.

Amir Khan enjoyed a day out with his family at a safari park in California. The Bolton-born boxer posed with a white tiger and fed giraffes during the trip to Six Flags Discovery Kingdom. It follows Khan's announcement that his next fight will be against Chris Algieri on May 30.

A new test for breast cancer can determine whether chemotherapy is necessary for a patient following surgery to remove a tumour.  The test, which works by analysing cancer cells for certain genetic markers, can inform a patient whether they are at high or low risk of the cancer returning and whether chemotherapy will be an effective treatment.  Although the majority of breast cancer patients are given chemotherapy following surgery, experts have believed that the risk of recurrence is lot less for certain women and that chemotherapy may not be required in all cases.  The test could spare many women the gruelling side effects of chemotherapy, which can include hair loss, nausea and extreme fatigue.

Transport for London (TFL) has revealed that the controversial posters will be removed from the London Underground as they had come to the end of the three week advertising period that Protein World had paid for. The company has said it will consider customer reaction in future. The posters will be removed tomorrow. It was reported that a bomb threat, that has been reported to the police, was made against the company.

The caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are concerned with looming budget cuts from the state of Illinois that would eliminate the state historic preservation agency, and a recent unflattering critique in National Geographic Magazine. The agency is in charge of the tomb, and the cuts could threaten historic site's management. The tomb was recently renovated, and is in excellent physical condition. However, the site has reduced hours and fewer employees since state lawmakers cut $1.1 million funding for sites in the Springfield area. The tomb was criticized in National Geographic as having "all the historical character of an office lobby.

Carriers of the BRCA1 gene who have had breast cancer can reduce their risk of dying by having their ovaries and fallopian tubes removed, a new study shows. The study found a 62% reduction in the risk of dying among those who had the procedure, known as an oophorectomy. It is the second major operation Hollywood star Angelina Jolie, who carries the gene, has had to combat her high risk of breast and ovarian cancer. She had a double mastectomy two years ago. Jolie had the second operation in March this year. Researchers called for further study on the effects of oophorectomies on carriers of the BRCA2 gene.

Using the provided game summary, here is what happened during the youth cup final:

- Tammy Abraham gave Chelsea the lead in the first half, scoring twice with volleys. 
- Isaac Buckley-Rickett brought Manchester City level in the first half with a measured finish.
- Dominic Solanke scored late on for Chelsea to put a gloss on the scoreline. 

This gives Chelsea a 3-1 lead in the series as the second leg gets underway.

Tammy Abraham scored a double to give Chelsea a 3-1 lead in the Youth Cup final against Manchester City. Dominic Solanke also scored for the away side, while Isaac Buckley-Rickett scored for the home team.

Research has shown that children who share iPads in class outperform those who don't have access to the devices, or who use them on their own. However, the best outcomes were found when children shared a device, suggesting that it is the collaborative learning around the technology that is making the difference. As a result, schools are being urged to reconsider how tablets are used in early grades to make them more effective.

Chinese parents are obsessed with raising child prodigies. A new basketball prodigy named Mai Zizhuo has been discovered in a viral video where he displays impressive basketball skills. The five year old has been playing basketball since he was 2 1/2 and his skills have won him thousands of fans across China.

England are increasingly looking like the last major rugby union nation to select players on the basis of their country of residence. The RFU’s intransigence is already seeing players like Steffon Armitage and Nick Abendanon improve by playing in France. The policy also prevents England from picking players like Drew Mitchell and Matt Giteau, who are playing fantastically well for Toulon. The RFU’s stance is not about being loyal to English clubs, the clubs actually benefit from a strong England team. It’s time for England to follow Australia’s lead and pick the best players available, regardless of where they play.

Conor McGregor is challenging Jose Aldo for the featherweight title in Las Vegas on July 11.
The Irishman has revealed a tiger's face tattoo on his stomach, next to the gorilla eating a heart on his chest.
McGregor feels he has more motivation than Aldo, who he branded as lacking the same fire as the 26-year-old.
When the pair were on a promotional tour of Dublin, McGregor grabbed the belt and raised it in front of 5,000 supporters.

Dani Alves has rejected Barcelona's contract offer and will leave the club this summer, with the player's agent and ex-wife stating that the negotiations are over. The club had offered him a three-year contract extension dependent on playing 60% of matches, but Santana stated this made no sense.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton has signed a new one-year contract after making a successful return from injury.
The 25-year-old missed the entire 2014 season after sustaining leg injuries in a road accident which killed his father.
He played again in pre-season and has now committed to the county until the end of 2016.

Officials from the World Health Organisation (WHO) have warned that caesarean sections are being performed too often and without sufficient medical cause.  According to the UN, these unnecessary procedures are putting the lives of mothers and their babies at risk, as they can lead to infections, disability, and even death. In England, the rate of caesareans has risen to over 25%, with a growing number of women opting for planned surgeries due to tokophobia, or extreme anxiety regarding natural childbirth. WHO officials have stated that the ideal rate of caesareans should be between 10-15%, due to the dangers and costs involved with the procedure. A planned caesarean costs the NHS an average of £2,369, compared to a natural birth costing £1665 on average. The WHO has advised that caesareans should only be conducted when medically necessary.

This collection of props and puppets from the movies of Make-up Effects Artist Rick Baker—who has worked on films like Planet of the Apes, Batman & Robin, Hellboy, and Mighty Joe Young—is set to be auctioned off at the end of May. Some of the items set to be auctioned include the grinch costume from How the Grinch Stole Christmas (valued at $8,000), the two-face mask from Batman Forever ($1,500), and an alien bug from Men in Black ($40,000). The auction is expected to fetch about $746,100 total.

Yoshinori Muto has admitted he is still considering an offer from Chelsea.
The Blues have made an offer, believed to be around £4m, for the Japan international.
Muto, 22, says he is keen to join a club where he will play regularly.
Muto would look to join Vitesse Arnhem on loan if he moves to Stamford Bridge.
Ranko Popovic, Muto's manager at FC Tokyo, believes he could be a big hit in the Premier League.
Chelsea signed a £200m sponsorship deal with Yokohoma Rubber in February.

There was a spike in flu-related deaths in Europe and the US.
Scientists have included protection against influenza A strain H3N2 and influenza B strain B/Phuket.
High risk groups can access free government funded flu shots from April 20.

Sleepy head is the name of a YouTube clip where Californian user Lionel Hutz's young son chases the family cat around the garden to use it as a pillow. The cat is not impressed and repeatedly moves before being gently fed treats by the boy later on.

Four British sailors currently posted in Nova Scotia have been charged with the gang rape of a local woman and are being held at a local military base pending trial. The men will be required to post £2,000 each in bail and will be required to live at the naval base as a condition of their bail. The men will also be required to keep their jobs with the Royal Navy and are prohibited from contacting the victim or witnesses. The alleged crime carries a 14 year prison sentence.

Leeds-based company Direct Line are running a competition #everydayfix, which has resulted in several prototype products being designed to tackle everyday problems. Problems include: forgetting to lock the door, losing your keys, being stuck in traffic, losing an important paper or document, and running out of battery on your phone. The top emergency identified in a survey of 2,000 people was not being able to sleep, and products designed to tackle this include an alarm clock that connects to your phone and silences notifications. The winner of the competition, to be voted for by retweeting tweets about the products with the hashtag #everydayfix, will go into development funded through a Kickstarter campaign.

Leeds-based company Direct Line are running a competition #everydayfix, which has resulted in several prototype products being designed to tackle everyday problems. Problems include: forgetting to lock the door, losing your keys, being stuck in traffic, losing an important paper or document, and running out of battery on your phone. The top emergency identified in a survey of 2,000 people was not being able to sleep, and products designed to tackle this include an alarm clock that connects to your phone and silences notifications. The winner of the competition, to be voted for by retweeting tweets about the products with the hashtag #everydayfix, will go into development funded through a Kickstarter campaign.

It covers the following pieces of information: 
Six people were injured in an explosion at an oil storage facility at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian Province, China. The blast occurred Monday night due to an oil leak. Five of the six injured were hurt by broken glass with one sent to the hospital in critical condition. There has been no report of a toxic chemical spill by local media. The fire is currently under control and more than 600 firefighters have been dispatched. Residents living close to the plant expressed concern on Weibo, and protests have occurred in the area in recent years against the plant's production of paraxylene (PX), a carcinogenic chemical. The plant was originally slated for Xiamen, but relocation to its current remote location occurred due to pollution concerns.

The passage discusses the alarming increase in the number of children born with Foetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS). According to the World Health Organisation, at least one in 100 UK babies are born with FAS, which can cause physical, learning and behavioural problems. These include deformed limbs, cerebral palsy and sight loss. It is believed that the actual number of children affected by FAS may be much higher, as the condition is often under-diagnosed. The government advises pregnant women to avoid alcohol, but some experts believe this guidance should be strengthened to encourage complete abstinence.

Indiana's Gov. Mike Pence approved a short-term needle exchange program last month to help curb the state's largest-ever HIV outbreak. In the first weeks of the program, 5,322 clean syringes have been provided to 86 participants, and about 1,400 used syringes have been returned. However, as the number of HIV cases grows, pressure mounts on Pence to extend the program beyond April 25. Pence, who opposes needle exchanges as an anti-drug policy, has said he will decide early next week.

A new video shows a Labrador called Cooper eating his McDonald's ice cream in one bite. His owner, Katie Gallegos says Cooper always eats quickly, so she makes sure his pal Daisy, eats first. To date the video of Cooper's ice cream outing has been watched more than seven million times.

The passage highlights the high landing fees faced by those who travel via private jet; a privilege only afforded to the ultra wealthy. The piece notes that the fees can give insight into which airports are most popular for the super rich, and lists 10 airports by the high cost of their landing fees. In order they are: 
1. Haneda Airport, Tokyo 
2. Narita International Airport, Tokyo 
3. Kansai International Airport, Osaka 
4. Toronto Pearson International Airport, Toronto 
5. Darwin International Airport, Darwin 
6. Bristol Airport, Bristol 
7. Chūbu Centrair International Airport, Nagoya 
8. Dublin Airport
9. La Guardia Airport, New York 
10. Salzburg Airport, Salzburg 

The passage also notes that Tokyo's Haneda airport is by far the most expensive, charging £4,559 ($6,850) for landing privileges and serving almost 69 million passengers per year.

New research shows that the art of washing one's own car is dying out in Britain -- only 12% of men say they do it regularly, and a whopping 71% of women never wash their own cars. As reasons, survey participants cited the rise of hand car washes, the prevalence of football on television on Sundays, and the fact that many cars are too large to clean. Brits are most likely to wash their own cars during holidays, with 15 million estimated to have done so during the recent Easter break. The study was conducted by vehicle leasing firm OSV, which surveyed 1,100 adults.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting sales registers at company-operated stores across the United States and Canada. The disruption, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, prompted baristas to give away free drinks and baked goods. Many locations closed to prevent giving away free products. The company released a statement saying that they are working to resolve the outage, and that stores will remain open. This comes just one day after the company posted record quarterly earnings.

Open Garden's FireChat allows users to chat to friends without the need for the web or a mobile signal. It does this by accessing iOS 7's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF), which creates a wireless mesh network that connects phones to each other, allowing messages to be sent via Bluetooth or Wi-Fi Direct. Greenstone acts as a beacon or booster for these networks, helping to strengthen and extend them. FireChat has been downloaded more than 5 million times and Greenstone is currently under development. It is expected to reach commercial availability sometime this year.

Jack Grealish, an Irish international footballer at Aston Villa, is superstitious and refuses to cover his shins with his socks as he believes this brings him luck. He made his first Premier League start on Tuesday against QPR. He hopes to get more starts before the end of the season.

Tim Sherwood, Aston Villa manager, has told Jack Grealish to focus on becoming a first team regular at Villa Park and not be concerned with his international future, as the 19-year-old is wanted by England and the Republic of Ireland. Grealish, who recently signed a new contract at Villa, made his first team debut in March 2015, and has made 22 appearances to date. Sherwood says he told Nabil Bentaleb, now at Tottenham, to go with his heart when he was deciding whether to play for Algeria or France, and that's what he's telling Grealish to do as well.

Sarah Wilson, journalist and author, opens up about her battle with mental illness, specifically anxiety. She explains that her anxiety and depression led her to contemplate taking her own life. She describes the point as being one where she could not see a way out and referred to it as an "existential crisis". She believes that her anxiety and depression are intrinsically linked and that this is a common phenomenon.

Laura Scurr was obsessed with having a perfect figure and blended mashed potato into her meals to hide the fact she wasn't eating.
The 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, whose heart rate had slowed after just a week of eating virtually nothing, collapsed and was rushed to hospital.
She spent a week on a heart monitor at North Tyneside General Hospital before she was offered support by eating disorder organisations and began her recovery.

The core pieces of information are as follows:
- A suicide bomber in Afghanistan killed 17 people and wounded 64 others.
- The bomber attacked a group of protesters, including Afghan lawmaker Faizullah Ghairat.
- The protesters were headed to a larger rally to protest the provincial governor. 
- The Taliban has denied responsibility for the attack. No other organization has claimed responsibility.

Gary Locke has signed a deal to become Kilmarnock manager on a permanent basis after an interim spell following the departure of Allan Johnston. Johnston, Locke's former team mate at Tynecastle, left Rugby Park at the start of February with the club struggling near the foot of the Scottish Premiership table. Kilmarnock have lost just once in seven games since 41-year-old Locke's arrival and he has now signed a three-year deal.

Four Liverpool players were surprised when they met YouTube star and free-kick specialist Bas van Velzen at their training ground.
Van Velzen, who has become a sensation by uploading free-kick videos to YouTube, met Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert and Lazar Markovic after winning a competition.

Every day, Lu Xin Cai takes his Alzheimer's suffering 84-year-old mother on the back of his motorbike to work. He ties a sash around both their waists for safety. When he was younger, his mother would often go up to the mountains to collect firewood and a few times, she got lost. After his father passed away, Xin Cai is the only one who can look after her as his wife works in a different city and his son is still in school. Even when at work, he checks up on his mother as his employers, a bank, gave her her own room.

Manchester United have made an official approach for PSV Eindhoven's Memphis Depay, with the club's technical director confirming their interest.
United manager Louis van Gaal is familiar with the player, having selected him for Holland's 2014 World Cup squad.
The versatile Depay can play on the left or right wing and his impressive dribbling skills see him complete the most dribbles in the entire Eredivise.
The 21-year-old has scored 20 goals in 26 league games for PSV this season and was the Dutch league's top scorer this year.
He has already made over 100 appearances for the Dutch giants and is under contract until 2018.

United manager Louis van Gaal is familiar with the player, having selected him for Holland's 2014 World Cup squad.
The versatile Depay can play on the left or right wing and his impressive dribbling skills see him complete the most dribbles in the entire Eredivise.
The 21-year-old has scored 20 goals in 26 league games for PSV this season and was the Dutch league's top scorer this year.
He scored in PSV's 4-1 win over Heerenveen which sealed the Dutch title.
Depay, who was born in 1994, started out at VV Moordrecht before joining Sparta Rotterdam aged nine and then moving to PSV aged 12.
He signed his first professional contract in June 2012 and has made over 100 appearances for the Dutch giants.

Robin van Persie will not feature in the Manchester Derby on Sunday due to a persistent ankle injury as announced by Manchester United manager Louis Van Gaal on Friday. Despite Van Persie's earlier comments that he was fit to play, Van Gaal does not believe the player is match fit. Luke Shaw is also out of the game due to lack of match fitness, however, Van Gaal said he cannot yet rule out either player's return as he believes in making his own decisions on when players are ready. The Dutch manager is looking forward to the game, saying "I dream of it. Every player should dream of the victory". Van Gaal goes into the game hoping to finish in the top three of the Premier League and avoid a Champions League play-off.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has admitted that he is disappointed in the performances of Yaya Toure this season but says that the midfielder will have his support until the end of the season.
Sportsmail revealed that City will listen to offers for Toure in the summer as they look to overhaul an ageing squad. Toure, who has two years left on his £220,000-a-week deal, has come under criticism amid the collapse of City's Premier League defence. Pellegrini said, "I don't think he's happy with his performance this year -- and nor am I," the Chilean said. "He doesn't need a break.

Martin Skrtel believes that Steven Gerrard, who is set to leave Liverpool at the end of the season, is one of the best players in the world and will be sorely missed, but that the team has the personnel to fill the void. Skrtel said that Gerrard had helped him immensely since he joined the club and that he was grateful for that. Liverpool face Aston Villa in the FA Cup semi-final on Sunday, with the winner set to face either Arsenal or Reading in the final.

Michael Shemansky is on the run after it is believed he murdered his mother. Shemansky failed to appear for a visit with his son on the same day as his mother's death. He has a history of bipolar disorder and was committed to a psychiatric ward for an attempted suicide in the past. His mother was helping him through divorce proceedings. It is believed the stress caused by the divorce caused him to murder his mother. He is on parole for battery of a law enforcement officer.

Mike Brown is being cautious over a recent concussion and refuses to put a time scale on his return for Harlequins. Brown recently pulled out of the England-Ireland game feeling the after-effects of a headache. This is in response to increased awareness of the symptoms of concussion that players undergo as part of their world rugby online modules.

Brown recently pulled out of the England-Ireland game feeling the after-effects of a headache. This is in response to increased awareness of the symptoms of concussion that players undergo as part of their world rugby online modules.

Mr Mole is 7-2 co-favourite for the Grade One Celebration Chase which AP McCoy will ride on his last day as a professional jockey. The Paul Nicholls-trained horse will be one of seven running in the race at Sandown on Saturday, with Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's Sacre the other co-favourites. It was after riding Mr Mole to victory at Newbury in February that McCoy revealed his decision to retire.

The New York City police hope that the public can help identify a woman found dead last month in Brooklyn so they can notify her family. The NYPD released images of a distinctive tattoo on her right leg to help with identification. Anyone with information is asked to contact the NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

Eden Hazard and young Nathan Ake took part in Audi's football challenge, paired up against Loic Remy and Willian in a series of football-related games for the car manufacturers. The first challenge was to fire balls into the boot of a car from close range, which was won by Hazard and Ake, who won 5-3. The second challenge was to sink balls into convertible Audis from long range, which was again won by Hazard and Ake, winning the decider to take a 6-0 lead after the first two rounds. In the final challenge, which earned the most points, the players had to shoot from long range aiming to sink their footballs through the roof of a convertible Audi. Remy and Willian won this, but in the process, Willian smashed the wing mirror off one of the Audis with a long-range effort, prompting a comical reaction from Loic Remy.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde left London over a year ago with no plans, no agenda and no cause to fight for. Rather, the Spanish and Latvian cyclists simply had a dream to see more of the planet. In the 356 days since then, they've covered 7,000 miles on bikes, spending less than three euros per day between them. Their budget keeps down costs by relying on free accommodation and no transport costs, and they pitch a tent or camp most nights. This leaves food as their main expense, with the pair eating pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, seasonal fruits and vegetables, and occasionally picking up wild fruits.
